III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Samaritas Shelter Grand Rapids program consists of three individual homes which are
single-story homes with fully furnished basements. This 45-bed facility is located on
2

Knapp Street in Northeast Grand Rapids, Michigan. Upon arrival to the facility the
driveway is shared with another facility and Samaritas Shelter homes are located on the
east side of the property. The three Samaritas Shelter homes are numbered 1, 2, and 3
and are all in a row next to a large baseball field and playground structure. Samaritas
Shelter home 3 is the first house nearest the road, then home 2, and lastly home 1
which is located at end of the driveway and next to a wooded area.
The Samaritas Shelter homes are all constructed in the same manner with the
exception of house 3 being the handicapped house and having an elevator in the home.
Upon entry to Samaritas Shelter homes there is an entryway which leads into a large
open space which includes a fully furnished dining room, living room, and kitchen. The
dining room had several rectangular shaped tables with six chairs around each. The
kitchen is very spacious with a bar area with stools for additional seating. The living
room area has a television, couches, and a chairs. There is an external doorway off
each of the kitchens which leads onto a deck area. There are two hallways off the dining
room. One of the hallways has two bedrooms on each side along with a bathroom on
each side for a total of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. There is an external door at
the end of the hallway. The other hallway is longer and in house 1 has an elevator to the
left, the other houses all include a laundry room, a staff bathroom, staff office directly
across from the staff bathroom, a storage closet on the right in houses 1 and 2, two
bedrooms on the left, two bedrooms on the right, and a bathroom on either side. There
is an external door at the end of the hallway. There are eight rooms total in each house
all furnished with bunkbeds and dressers in the room, there will be a maximum of 15
youth in each house with one bedroom being a “single” room and all other rooms being
“doubles”. There is a stairwell off the dining room which leads to a fully furnished
basement area. Upon entering the basement there is an area with a bathroom, closet,
and deep freezer, across from that area is a large open space that will be used as a
second living area for the youth. Houses 1 and 2 are not currently furnished however
House 3 had a pool table, foosball table, couches, and a television.
B. Program Description
Samaritas Shelter, Grand Rapids program is a residential transitional Foster Care
shelter for Unaccompanied Alien Children (UAC) youth needing temporary
comprehensive services. The program is a 45-bed shelter which serves males ages 13
to 17. The program cares for youth who must demonstrate the ability to manage their
behavior and be advancing toward a goal of family reunification. Youth may have mild
behavioral or mental health issues. The program is not designed to accept high risk
youth, including those who are physically or sexually aggressive, have a history of
setting fires, or are inappropriate for a community-based setting. The average length of
stay would be no more than 45 days.
During placement residents receive 24-hour care, safety assessment and planning,
educational assessment, and continued classroom education with concentration on
basic academic competencies and English Language training, legal orientation and
assessment, clinical assessment and counseling (individual once a week and group
once a week), case management services, and recreational services. Residents will
3

have a health screen within 24 hours of program entry, and a full medical exam by a
local licensed physician within 48 hours of admission, excluding weekends and
holidays. They will also have a visit with a licensed physician for oral, eye, and hearing
exams. The staff-to-resident ratio is 1:10 during waking hours and 1:20 during sleeping
hours. The facility will have no form of seclusion or restraint for the residents. Facility
staff will be trained in the use of Aegis for de-escalation and restraint purposes.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
There are currently no rule/statutory violations.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend that an original provisional license be issued to this private child
caring institution.
